{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3495268,"name":"","username":"VimalBuckley","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/6bbea6/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-29T01:14:58.732Z","cooked":"

Our programming team has been given a robot to characterize and test, and we want to preform SysID on our mechanisms. The problem that we’re running into is that it is near impossible to get enough good data on our arm in the downwards direction, due to how soon we have to stop it before it hits our robot.

Could we lay our robot sideways, so that gravity doesn’t affect the speed of the elevator, in order to get our kV and kA gains? And then manually find our kS and kG gains using this technique?

I’m assuming this would give inaccurate data, but it if works it could be very convenient!

Thanks!

VimalBuckley:

Could we lay our robot sideways, so that gravity doesn’t affect the speed of the elevator, in order to get our kV and kA gains? And then manually find our kS and kG gains using this technique?

Yes, you can.

alternatively you could tune kG manually first and then tune kA and kV with sysID while the kG is active

Why wouldn’t it? It’s now a turret.

Do be mindful to analyze the data as a simple motor, not an arm, since you’re not expecting to see a kG term in the data.
